message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with benign prostatic enlargement, and among the options, only Finasteride is used to treat this condition by inhibiting the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone, which can decrease the size of the prostate gland. Tamsulosin is also used to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia by relaxing the muscles of the prostate and bladder neck, but it is not the initial treatment of choice. Tadalafil is used to treat erectile dysfunction but does not treat the underlying cause of the patient’s symptoms. Leuprolide is used in the treatment of prostate cancer and is not appropriate for this patient.

Tamsulosin can help improve urine flow, but does not reduce the size of the prostate. Tadalafil is indicated for erectile dysfunction and Leuprolide is used for prostate cancer treatment.

Finasteride, a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor, is a commonly used medication for benign prostatic hyperplasia and is an appropriate option for this patient. Tadalafil is used for erectile dysfunction and Leuprolide is used for prostate cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical exam findings suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Among the options, only Finasteride inhibits the enzyme responsible for converting testosterone to dihydrotestosterone, which is responsible for the growth of the prostate. Tamsulosin helps relax the smooth muscle in the prostate and bladder neck, but doesn’t shrink the prostate. Tadalafil and leuprolide are not indicated for BPH.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and examination findings suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Finasteride is a 5-alpha reductase inhibitor that reduces the size of the prostate gland, which can improve urinary symptoms in patients with BPH. Tamsulosin is an alpha1-blocker that can also improve urinary symptoms in patients with BPH, but it does not reduce the size of the prostate gland. Tadalafil is a phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE5) inhibitor that is used to treat erectile dysfunction but has not been shown to improve urinary symptoms in patients with BPH. Leuprolide is a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist that is used in the treatment of prostate cancer but is not indicated for BPH.
